{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2002 |Team=USC Trojans |Image=Interlocking_USC_Logo.svg |ImageSize=100 |Conference=Pacific-10 Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Pac-10 |APRank=4 |CoachRank=4 |Record=11â2 |ConfRecord=7â1 |HeadCoach=[[Pete Carroll]] |OffCoach=[[Norm Chow]] |DefCoach= |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]] |Champion=Orange Bowl Champions
Pac-10 Co-Champions |BowlTourney=[[2003 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] vs. [[2002 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|Iowa]] |BowlTourneyResult= W 38â17 }} {{2002 Pacific-10 football standings}} The '''2002 [[USC Trojans football]] team''' represented the [[University of Southern California]] in the [[2002 NCAA Division I-A football season|2002-2003 NCAA Division I-A college football season]]. USC ended the regular season ranked #5 in both the [[AP Poll]] and the [[Coaches' Poll]]. Trojans quarterback [[Carson Palmer]] won the 2002 [[Heisman Trophy]] as the best college football player in America. During the [[bowl games]], USC had a convincing 38â17 win over #3 [[Iowa Hawkeyes football|Iowa]] in the [[2003 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]]. USC became #4 in the final AP Poll and Coaches' Poll. ==Recruiting== USC was ranked highly (#12 by Scout, #13 by Rivals) for getting [[Darnell Bing]], [[Manuel Wright]], [[Winston Justice]], [[Fred Matua]], [[Tom Malone (American football)|Tom Malone]], [[Jason Mitchell]], [[Hershel Dennis]], [[Kyle Williams (offensive tackle)|Kyle Williams]], [[Dominique Byrd]], [[Dallas Sartz]], [[Justin Wyatt]], [[Chris McFoy]], [[Mike Williams (wide receiver b. 1984)|Mike Williams]], [[LaJuan Ramsey]], [[Oscar Lua]] and [[Brandon Hancock]] among others. ==Schedule== The Trojans finished the season with a 11â2 record, 7â1 in the Pac-10.[http://usctrojans.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/012604aaa.html] {{CFB Schedule Start | time = yes | rank = yes | ranklink = yes | rankyear = 2002 | tv = yes
